channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: C.I.A. Conducted Drone Strike on Port in Venezuela
item.description: The attack last week, on a dock purportedly used for shipping narcotics, did not kill anyone, people briefed on the operation said. But it was the first known U.S. operation inside Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaking to reporters on Monday, President Trump had declined to say how the attack had been carried out or by whom but confirmed the United States was responsible.

item.title: Grim Evidence of Trump’s Boat Strikes Washes Ashore on a Colombian Peninsula
item.description: First came the scorched boat. Then the mangled bodies. Then the packets with traces of marijuana. Now, fishermen fear the ocean that feeds them.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Simón Posada, Christiaan Triebert and Federico Rios
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

item.title: U.S. Kills 2 in Strike in Pacific, as Trump Pressures Venezuela
item.description: The attack was the 30th announced by the U.S. military since early September. It came days after President Trump said the U.S. had struck a coastal site related to drugs and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The strike, conducted at the direction of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, had targeted a boat sailing along a “known narco-trafficking route” in the eastern Pacific.

item.title: Trump and Netanyahu Praise Each Other After Meeting, Despite Differences Over Gaza
item.description: The American and Israeli leaders showed few signs of disagreement after meeting in Florida, giving no public indication of their growing strains over Gaza, Syria and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: New Year’s Eve Concerts at Kennedy Center Are Canceled
item.description: The jazz drummer Billy Hart said the decision was “evidently” connected to President Trump’s name being added to the arts center.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Neil Vigdor
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The head of Doug Varone and Dancers called the decision to cancel two performances at the Kennedy Center “financially devastating but morally exhilarating.”

item.title: Justice Department Sues Virginia Over Tuition Aid for Unauthorized Immigrants
item.description: The department said the state’s policy of granting unauthorized immigrants in-state financial aid at public colleges and universities violates federal law.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville, Va.

item.title: U.S. Pledges $2 Billion for U.N. Aid but Trump Administration Tells Agencies to ‘Adapt, Shrink, or Die’
item.description: The announcement will likely keep the United States as the biggest international aid donor next year, even as the Trump administration slashes funding for foreign assistance programs.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bags of rations being unloaded at a World Food Program distribution point last year at a temporary camp for refugees from Sudan in Adre, Chad.

item.title: With Artillery and Warships, China Practices Blockading Taiwan
item.description: China flew bombers and fired long-range artillery during a second day of exercises designed to show its ability to claim the island-democracy by force.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Adek Berry/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese military fired a rocket on Tuesday from Pingtan, an island in the eastern province of Fujian that is China’s closest point to Taiwan.

item.title: Yonaguni, the Japanese Island on the Front Lines of China’s Feud with Japan
item.description: Yonaguni, a tiny Japanese island near Taiwan, is getting soldiers, radar and missiles. As China’s dispute with Tokyo escalates, some residents are worried.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Hisako Ueno and Ko Sasaki
item.media:description: Yonaguni, a Japanese military outpost about 70 miles east of Taiwan, sits along the so-called “first island chain,” a strategic arc of islands used to hem in Chinese naval expansion.

item.title: Inside Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Break With Trump and MAGA
item.description: How the Georgia congresswoman went from the president’s loudest cheerleader to his loudest Republican critic.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times

item.title: Four Takeaways From the New York Times Profile of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The congresswoman discussed her break with President Trump and her journey from MAGA zealot to political isolation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greene and her staff at the Capitol complex in mid-December, when she cast her final vote on her last day working in Washington.

item.title: Trump, Pressing Ahead on Ukraine-Russia Talks, Confronts Difficult Realities
item.description: The U.S.-led negotiations have made some progress, but still face fundamental challenges, including over security guarantees to counter future Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with a Ukrainian antiaircraft defense unit monitoring the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region last week.

item.title: Russia Threatens to Toughen Its Stance on Ending the War in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow said a Ukrainian drone attack targeted a residence of President Vladimir V. Putin, which Ukraine denied, accusing the Kremlin of fabricating an excuse not to make peace.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel/Sputnik
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with military officers in Moscow on Monday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh’s First Female Prime Minister, Dies
item.description: A leader for three terms, she traded the country’s leadership with Sheikh Hasina, the head of another political dynasty, over decades. She was believed to be 80.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Khaled Hasan for The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani Will Be Sworn In at Abandoned Subway Station Beneath City Hall
item.description: Hours before Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani holds an inauguration block party outside City Hall, he will officially become mayor in a small private ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The old City Hall Station, which has been out of commission since 1945, is famous for its arches.

item.title: As Youth Sports Professionalize, Kids Are Burning Out Fast
item.description: A growing body of research shows how pressure from overbearing coaches and parents is stunting children’s emotional well-being and leading to injuries.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: A baseball game at Kentlake High School in Kent, Wash. According to a survey by the Aspen Institute, 11.4 percent of parents believe their children can play professionally.

item.title: How a Research Trip to Antarctica Deals With Time Zones
item.description: The clocks aboard our icebreaker will be changed several times en route to Antarctica. It’s one of many things that make the expedition feel otherworldly.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Hundreds Sue Virginia Hospital and Executives Over Unneeded Surgeries
item.description: More than 500 women claimed that they had received unnecessary operations. Hospital leaders said they were not aware of a doctor’s misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Western Tidewater Regional Jail, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Javaid Perwaiz is serving a 59-year prison sentence after being convicted of health care fraud arising from medically unnecessary surgeries at Chesapeake Regional Medical Center in Chesapeake, Va.

item.title: 10 Fitness Tips to Help You Get Moving in 2026
item.description: Turn your walk into a better workout, build strength without weights and more exercise advice for the year ahead.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: One of America’s Most Successful Experiments Is Coming to a Shuddering Halt
item.description: Amid an astonishing wave of anti-Indian animus, Indian Americans are questioning their place in the country.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Miraj Patel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indian immigrants in the United States have found success, and unexpected hostility.

item.title: Saudis Say Airstrike in Yemen Targeted Arms From U.A.E.
item.description: The Saudi-led coalition said its strike, at a port in southern Yemen, targeted weapons bound for a separatist group backed by the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Fawaz Salman/Reuters
item.media:description: Soldiers loyal to the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group backed by the United Arab Emirates, in Aden, Yemen, early this month.

item.title: Melanie Watson Bernhardt, ‘Diff’rent Strokes’ Actress, Dies at 57
item.description: Her four episodes on the sitcom marked a rarity: a disabled actress onscreen.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Frank Carroll/NBC/NBCU Photo Bank
item.media:description: Melanie Watson Bernhardt played Kathy Gordon in the hit television show “Diff’rent Strokes” starring Gary Coleman.

item.title: New York City Takes Over Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn
item.description: Maimonides Health is a community fixture that will become part of NYC Health + Hospitals. Many of its patients are on government medical plans.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maimonides Health operates three hospitals and more than 80 other sites in Brooklyn.

item.title: Democrats Aim to Spotlight Republican Efforts to Rewrite the Jan. 6 Capitol Riot
item.description: On the fifth anniversary of the attack, which falls next Tuesday, Democrats plan to hold an informal hearing to review President Trump’s clemency for the rioters and G.O.P. attempts to sanitize the event.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trump supporters heading toward the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The ensuing riot caused millions of dollars in damage, injured more than 140 police officers and interrupted the certification of the presidential election.
